title: components
description: The components/ directory is where you put all your Vue components.

children.value: Nuxt automatically imports any components in this directory (along with components that are registered by any modules you may be using).

--| AppHeader.vue
--| AppFooter.vue

  <component :is="SomeComponent" />

children.value: to handle dynamic components, make sure not to insert anything but the name of the component, which must be a string and not a variable.
Alternatively, though not recommended, you can register all your components globally, which will create async chunks for all your components and make them available throughout your application.

props.className: language-diff shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight

children.value: You can also selectively register some components globally by placing them in a
suffix in the filename. As noted above, each global component is rendered in a separate chunk, so be careful not to overuse this feature.
option can also be set per component directory.
To dynamically import a component (also known as lazy-loading a component) all you need to do is add the
prefix to the component's name. This is particularly useful if the component is not always needed.
prefix you can delay loading the component code until the right moment, which can be helpful for optimizing your JavaScript bundle size.

You can also achieve a similar result with the

Server components allow server-rendering individual components within your client-side apps. It's possible to use server components within Nuxt, even if you are generating a static site. That makes it possible to build complex sites that mix dynamic components, server-rendered HTML and even static chunks of markup.
Server components can either be used on their own or paired with a
Watch Learn Vue video about Nuxt Server Components.
Read Daniel Roe's guide to Nuxt Server Components.
Standalone server components will always be rendered on the server, also known as Islands components.
When their props update, this will result in a network request that will update the rendered HTML in-place.
Server components are currently experimental and in order to use them, you need to enable the 'component islands' feature in your nuxt.config:

props.className: language-ts shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight twoslash lsp

children.value: By default it is set to 'auto', which means it will be enabled only when there are islands, server components or server pages in your app.
Now you can register server-only components with the
suffix and use them anywhere in your application automatically.

Server components (and islands) must have a single root element. (HTML comments are considered elements as well.)
Most features for server-only components and island components, such as slots and client components, are only available for single file components.

When rendering a server-only or island component,
makes a fetch request which comes back with a
. (This is an internal request if rendered on the server, or a request that you can see in the network tab if it's rendering on client-side navigation.)

A new 'island context' will be created while rendering the component.
You can't access the 'island context' from the rest of your app and you can't access the context of the rest of your app from the island component. In other words, the server component or island is
from the rest of your app.
Your plugins will run again when rendering the island, unless they have
set (which you can do in an object-syntax plugin).

. Note that while island components are still marked as experimental, the format of this context may change.
